title: Tulane University Commencement 2009 - Ellen DeGeneres

multiple-choice.question: Which of the following is an example of an intrinsic motivator?

options.label: A
options.text: A bonus for meeting a sales target

options.label: C
options.text: Personal satisfaction from completing a challenging project

multiple-choice.question: According to Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs, which of the following is a physiological need?

options.label: A
options.text: Completing a project by the end of the week

options.label: B
options.text: Getting a promotion within the next year

multiple-choice.question: According to the Self-Determination Theory, which of the following is a fundamental human need?

options.label: A
options.text: Receiving a bonus for every 10 sales made

options.label: B
options.text: Receiving a bonus for every sale made

options.label: C
options.text: Receiving a bonus at random intervals

options.label: D
options.text: Receiving a bonus for meeting a sales target

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Experiencing a physiological response to a stimulus

options.label: C
options.text: Engaging in a behavior to achieve a goal

options.label: D
options.text: Expressing an emotion through facial expressions

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: In praise of slowness - Carl Honore

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the movement that emphasizes the importance of slowing down in various aspects of life?
In which country did the Slow Food Movement start?
What is the main idea behind the concept of "good slow" in the context of the slow movement?

options.label: A
options.text: Taking the time to eat a meal with your family

options.label: B
options.text: Taking the time to look at a problem from all angles

options.label: C
options.text: Embracing a slower pace of life to improve overall well-being

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the cultural taboo that makes it difficult for people to slow down?

options.label: A
options.text: The idea that slowing down is lazy

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that slowing down is stupid

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that slowing down is a sign of weakness

multiple-choice.question: How can individuals apply the concept of "good slow" to their daily lives?

options.label: A
options.text: By taking regular breaks to relax and recharge

options.label: B
options.text: By prioritizing tasks and focusing on the most important ones

options.label: C
options.text: By embracing a slower pace of life and taking time to enjoy activities

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of how companies can apply the concept of "good slow" to their work culture?

options.label: A
options.text: By encouraging employees to work longer hours

options.label: B
options.text: By providing regular breaks and time for employees to relax and recharge

options.label: C
options.text: By prioritizing tasks and focusing on the most important ones

options.label: D
options.text: By reducing the number of employees

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's argument about the relationship between speed and productivity?

options.label: C
options.text: That there is a balance between speed and productivity, and that slowing down can sometimes be more productive

options.label: D
options.text: That speed has no impact on productivity

multiple-choice.question: How does the speaker's personal experience with slowing down relate to the broader concept of the slow movement?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows that slowing down is only beneficial for individuals, not for society as a whole

options.label: B
options.text: It shows that slowing down is only beneficial for certain aspects of life, such as work or relationships

options.label: C
options.text: It shows that slowing down can have a positive impact on overall well-being and relationships

options.label: D
options.text: It shows that slowing down is not possible in today's fast-paced world

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the impact of technology on our pace of life?

options.label: A
options.text: That technology is the main cause of our fast-paced lives

options.label: B
options.text: That technology is a tool that can be used to slow down or speed up our lives

options.label: C
options.text: That technology has no impact on our pace of life

options.label: D
options.text: That technology is the solution to our fast-paced lives

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's conclusion about the possibility of slowing down in today's world?

options.label: A
options.text: That it is impossible to slow down in today's world

options.label: B
options.text: That it is only possible to slow down in certain aspects of life

options.label: C
options.text: That it is possible to slow down and that it can have a positive impact on overall well-being

options.label: D
options.text: That it is only possible to slow down for individuals, not for society as a whole

title: How to use expertsâ€”and when not to - Noreena Hertz

multiple-choice.question: What is the main problem with our reliance on experts, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Experts are not knowledgeable in their fields.

options.label: B
options.text: Experts are not always right, but we have become too reliant on their certainty.

options.label: C
options.text: Experts are only motivated by financial gain.

options.label: D
options.text: Experts are not necessary in today's world.

multiple-choice.question: What was the result of a recent experiment where adults had their brain scanned while listening to experts speak?

options.label: A
options.text: The independent decision-making parts of their brains became more active.

options.label: B
options.text: The independent decision-making parts of their brains showed no change.

options.label: C
options.text: The independent decision-making parts of their brains switched off.

options.label: D
options.text: The emotional parts of their brains became more active.

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of experts getting it wrong, as mentioned by the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: Doctors correctly diagnosing patients 100% of the time.

options.label: B
options.text: Financial experts predicting the worst recession since the 1930s.

options.label: C
options.text: Financial experts failing to predict the worst recession since the 1930s.

options.label: D
options.text: Tax advisors filing tax returns correctly 100% of the time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's profession, and how does it relate to their argument about experts?

options.label: A
options.text: The speaker is a doctor, and they argue that medical experts are always right.

options.label: B
options.text: The speaker is an economist, and they argue that experts, including themselves, need to be more open-minded and democratic.

options.label: C
options.text: The speaker is a politician, and they argue that experts should not be trusted.

options.label: D
options.text: The speaker is a professor, and they argue that experts are always correct.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is a common thinking error of radiologists when looking at CT scans?

options.label: A
options.text: They are overly influenced by the patient's symptoms.

options.label: B
options.text: They are overly influenced by the referring physician's diagnosis.

options.label: C
options.text: They are not influenced by the patient's medical history.

options.label: D
options.text: They are not influenced by the referring physician's diagnosis.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's proposed solution to the problem of relying too heavily on experts?

options.label: A
options.text: We should never listen to experts.

options.label: B
options.text: We should always follow the advice of experts.

options.label: C
options.text: We should be more critical of experts and challenge their assumptions.

options.label: D
options.text: We should only listen to experts in certain fields.

multiple-choice.question: What is "managed dissent," and how can it be applied in a practical setting?

options.label: A
options.text: Managed dissent is the suppression of opposing views, and it can be applied by ignoring dissenting opinions.

options.label: B
options.text: Managed dissent is the encouragement of opposing views, and it can be applied by actively seeking out diverse perspectives.

options.label: C
options.text: Managed dissent is the avoidance of conflict, and it can be applied by avoiding discussions that may lead to disagreement.

options.label: D
options.text: Managed dissent is the imposition of one's own views, and it can be applied by forcing others to agree.

multiple-choice.question: How does the concept of "democratized expertise" challenge the conventional notion of expertise?

options.label: A
options.text: It suggests that expertise is only held by those with advanced degrees.

options.label: B
options.text: It suggests that expertise is limited to certain fields or professions.

options.label: C
options.text: It suggests that expertise can be held by anyone, regardless of their background or position.

options.label: D
options.text: It suggests that expertise is not necessary in today's world.

multiple-choice.question: What is the example given by the speaker of a company that successfully applied the concept of democratized expertise?

options.label: A
options.text: A company that only consulted with external experts.

options.label: B
options.text: A company that only relied on the opinions of its top executives.

options.label: C
options.text: A company that encouraged all employees to contribute their expertise and opinions.

options.label: D
options.text: A company that ignored the opinions of its employees.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the ultimate goal of challenging the conventional notion of expertise and embracing democratized expertise?

options.label: A
options.text: To eliminate the need for experts altogether.

options.label: B
options.text: To create a more hierarchical and authoritarian system.

options.label: C
options.text: To make better decisions by leveraging diverse perspectives and expertise.

options.label: D
options.text: To maintain the status quo and avoid change.

title: On being a woman and a diplomat - Madeleine Albright

multiple-choice.question: What inspired Madeleine Albright to start wearing pins that reflected her diplomatic messages?

options.label: A
options.text: She wanted to make a fashion statement.

options.label: B
options.text: Saddam Hussein compared her to an "unparalleled serpent" in a poem.

options.label: C
options.text: She was given a pin as a gift from a colleague.

options.label: D
options.text: She saw it as a way to distract from the issues at hand.

multiple-choice.question: What was Madeleine Albright's response to the criticism she faced as a woman in a high-level diplomatic position?

options.label: A
options.text: She ignored the criticism and focused on her work.

options.label: B
options.text: She changed her style to fit in with her male colleagues.

options.label: C
options.text: She used the criticism as an opportunity to speak out on women's issues.

options.label: D
options.text: She felt guilty and doubted her abilities.

multiple-choice.question: According to Madeleine Albright, what is the key to achieving a balance between being a strong diplomat and a nurturing figure?

options.label: A
options.text: Prioritizing one's own needs and desires.

options.label: B
options.text: Seeking support from colleagues and mentors.

options.label: C
options.text: Stepping out of one's comfort zone and taking risks.

multiple-choice.question: What was the significance of the "G7" group formed by Madeleine Albright at the UN?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a group of seven countries that shared similar economic interests.

options.label: B
options.text: It was a group of seven women who lobbied for women's issues.

options.label: C
options.text: It was a group of seven diplomats who worked on disarmament issues.

options.label: D
options.text: It was a group of seven experts who advised on sustainable development.

multiple-choice.question: What does Madeleine Albright believe is the impact of having more women at the negotiating table?

options.label: A
options.text: It leads to more conflict and competition.

options.label: B
options.text: It leads to more cooperation and compromise.

options.label: C
options.text: It has no significant impact on the outcome.

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on the individual women involved.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the organization that Madeleine Albright chairs, which supports women candidates?
What is Madeleine Albright's motto regarding women supporting each other?

options.label: A
options.text: "Women should always prioritize their own needs."

options.label: B
options.text: "There's a special place in hell for women who don't help each other."

options.label: C
options.text: "Women should always compromise and avoid conflict."

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the war crimes tribunal established during Madeleine Albright's tenure as Secretary of State?

options.label: A
options.text: It failed to prosecute any war crimes.

options.label: C
options.text: It declared rape a weapon of war and prosecuted those responsible.

options.label: D
options.text: It was disbanded due to lack of funding.

multiple-choice.question: According to Madeleine Albright, what is the key to achieving sustainable peace and conflict resolution?

options.label: C
options.text: Empowering women and promoting gender equality.

multiple-choice.question: What is Madeleine Albright's assessment of the current state of women's rights and empowerment globally?

options.label: A
options.text: Women have made significant progress and achieved equality.

options.label: B
options.text: Women still face significant barriers and challenges.

options.label: C
options.text: Women's rights are not a priority in most countries.

options.label: D
options.text: Women's empowerment is only relevant in Western countries.

title: See Yemen through my eyes - Nadia Al-Sakkaf

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the image of women and men leading a mixed protest in Yemen?

options.label: A
options.text: It shows the popularity of the president.

options.label: B
options.text: It highlights the need for change in the country.

options.label: C
options.text: It demonstrates the traditional role of women in Yemeni society.

options.label: D
options.text: It shows the impact of foreign influence on Yemeni culture.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's role in Yemeni society, according to her own description?

options.label: B
options.text: A bridge between the old and new societies

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's father's attitude towards her education and career?

options.label: A
options.text: He discouraged her from pursuing a career in journalism.

options.label: B
options.text: He encouraged her to follow traditional Yemeni roles for women.

options.label: C
options.text: He believed in equal opportunities for boys and girls.

options.label: D
options.text: He was not involved in her education or career.

multiple-choice.question: What challenges did the speaker face when she became the Editor-in-Chief of the Yemen Times?

options.label: A
options.text: She was not taken seriously by her male colleagues.

options.label: B
options.text: She was not familiar with the newspaper industry.

options.label: C
options.text: She faced opposition from the government.

multiple-choice.question: How did the speaker address the issue of women wearing the veil in the workplace?

options.label: A
options.text: She banned the veil in the office.

options.label: B
options.text: She encouraged women to wear the veil as a symbol of tradition.

options.label: C
options.text: She allowed women to choose whether or not to wear the veil.

options.label: D
options.text: She provided economic incentives for women to remove the veil.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's view on the Western media's coverage of Yemen?

options.label: A
options.text: She believes it is fair and balanced.

options.label: B
options.text: She thinks it is biased towards the government's perspective.

options.label: C
options.text: She believes it perpetuates stereotypes and lacks depth.

options.label: D
options.text: She is not familiar with Western media's coverage of Yemen.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the documentary "Shake the Dust"?

options.label: A
options.text: It highlights the traditional role of women in Yemeni society.

options.label: B
options.text: It showcases the hip-hop scene in Yemen.

options.label: C
options.text: It explores the impact of foreign influence on Yemeni culture.

options.label: D
options.text: It documents the history of the Yemen Times.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's prediction for Yemen's future?

options.label: A
options.text: She believes it will become a more traditional and conservative society.

options.label: B
options.text: She thinks it will become a more democratic and empowered society.

options.label: C
options.text: She is unsure about the country's future.

options.label: D
options.text: She believes it will remain the same.

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the Yemen Times' independence?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows the newspaper to promote the government's agenda.

options.label: B
options.text: It enables the newspaper to provide a unique and independent perspective.

options.label: C
options.text: It makes the newspaper more vulnerable to prosecution.

options.label: D
options.text: It has no impact on the newspaper's content.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's message to the Western media and the world?

options.label: A
options.text: She wants them to fear and hate Yemen.

options.label: B
options.text: She wants them to understand and respect Yemeni culture.

options.label: C
options.text: She wants them to ignore Yemen and its problems.

options.label: D
options.text: She wants them to provide economic aid to Yemen.

title: Why it pays to work hard - Richard St. John

multiple-choice.question: What is the second trait that successful people have in common, according to the speaker?
What term does the speaker use to describe people who work hard but also have fun doing it?
According to the speaker, what is the relationship between work and talent?

options.label: A
options.text: Work is less important than talent

options.label: B
options.text: Work is equally important as talent

options.label: C
options.text: Work is more important than talent

multiple-choice.question: What is an example of someone who had talent but didn't achieve success until they started working hard?
According to the speaker, what is the real gift that successful people have?
What is an example of someone who is not the smartest but achieved success through hard work?
According to the speaker, what is the key to success for people who are not the smartest?
What is the speaker's message to people who are smart but not achieving success?

options.label: A
options.text: They should rely on their intelligence to succeed

options.label: B
options.text: They should work harder to achieve their potential

options.label: C
options.text: They should give up because they will never succeed

options.label: D
options.text: They should focus on developing their talents

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between success and intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Success is directly related to intelligence

options.label: B
options.text: Success is indirectly related to intelligence

options.label: C
options.text: Success is not necessarily related to intelligence

options.label: D
options.text: Success is inversely related to intelligence

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final message to the audience?

options.label: A
options.text: Only smart people can achieve success

options.label: B
options.text: Only talented people can achieve success

options.label: C
options.text: Anyone can achieve success as long as they work hard

title: The key to media's hidden codes - Ben Beaton

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary function of technical codes in media?

options.label: A
options.text: To convey information in a straightforward manner

options.label: B
options.text: To create a sense of chaos and disorder

options.label: C
options.text: To make the audience think, act, or feel a certain way

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the context of a message

multiple-choice.question: What is a key characteristic of a code, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: It must be complex and difficult to understand

options.label: B
options.text: It must be recognized by all who read it

options.label: C
options.text: It must be used only in written communication

options.label: D
options.text: It must be used only in visual media

multiple-choice.question: What is the role of context in understanding codes?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the code more ambiguous

options.label: B
options.text: It has no impact on the meaning of the code

options.label: C
options.text: It helps to clarify the meaning of the code

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the code more complex

multiple-choice.question: Which branch of the family tree of technical codes is concerned with representation?
What is the purpose of using buzzwords in advertising?

options.label: A
options.text: To make a product seem less interesting

options.label: B
options.text: To plant a word in the subconscious that triggers a response

options.label: C
options.text: To ignore the needs and desires of the audience

options.label: D
options.text: To create a sense of boredom

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of placing the camera high above the subject in a shot?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the subject appear powerful and significant

options.label: B
options.text: It makes the subject appear small and insignificant

options.label: C
options.text: It has no impact on the audience's perception of the subject

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the subject appear neutral

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary idea that the video is trying to sell to the audience?

options.label: B
options.text: The idea that understanding technical codes is fun and interesting

options.label: C
options.text: The idea that advertising is manipulative and deceptive

options.label: D
options.text: The idea that media has no impact on our thoughts and feelings

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to understand technical codes in media?

options.label: A
options.text: So that we can ignore their impact on us

options.label: B
options.text: So that we can be more easily manipulated by advertisers

options.label: C
options.text: So that we can be aware of their techniques and identify their impact on us

options.label: D
options.text: So that we can create more complex and confusing codes

multiple-choice.question: What is one of the most powerful advertising mediums in the world, according to the transcript?
What is the ultimate goal of the video, according to the transcript?

options.label: A
options.text: To confuse and overwhelm the audience with information

options.label: B
options.text: To persuade the audience to buy a particular product

options.label: C
options.text: To educate the audience about the importance of understanding technical codes

options.label: D
options.text: To ignore the audience's needs and desires

title: 8 traits of successful people - Richard St. John

multiple-choice.question: What does the speaker describe himself as, rather than a motivational speaker?
Who is the speaker's hero, known for running thousands of miles and raising millions for cancer research?

options.label: A
options.text: Running a marathon in under 2 hours

options.label: B
options.text: Climbing the highest mountain in Africa

options.label: B
options.text: By running 422 laps around the deck of a boat

options.label: D
options.text: By cycling on a stationary bike

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's response to the teenage girl's question about being successful?

options.label: A
options.text: He says he is not successful

options.label: B
options.text: He says he is a millionaire

options.label: C
options.text: He says success is not important

options.label: D
options.text: He says he has had some success

multiple-choice.question: What is the teenage girl's concern about achieving success?

options.label: A
options.text: She is worried about being too smart

options.label: B
options.text: She is worried about being too old

options.label: C
options.text: She is worried about being too poor

options.label: D
options.text: She is worried about not being smart enough

options.text: He tells her to focus on making money

options.label: B
options.text: He tells her to focus on being popular

options.label: C
options.text: He tells her that if he can do it, she can do it

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's approach to finding out what leads to success?
What are the 8 traits that the speaker discovers are common to most people's success?

options.label: A
options.text: Love what you do, work hard, focus on one thing, keep pushing yourself, come up with good ideas, keep improving yourself, serve others, and be lucky

options.label: B
options.text: Love what you do, work hard, focus on one thing, keep pushing yourself, come up with good ideas, keep improving yourself, serve others, and persist

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the foundation of success?

options.label: C
options.text: The 8 traits (love what you do, work hard, focus on one thing, keep pushing yourself, come up with good ideas, keep improving yourself, serve others, and persist)

title: The power of passion - Richard St. John

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the first trait that successful people have in common?
What did Russell Crowe say was the reason for his Academy Award for Best Actor?

options.label: B
options.text: He had a great passion for acting

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's suggestion for people who are in a job they don't love?

options.label: B
options.text: Follow their passion on the side

options.label: C
options.text: Stay in the job for the money

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what percentage of successful people's time should be spent on things they love?
What did James Dyson say he loved, and would continue to love until the day he dies?
What did Bill Gates say was the reason he became successful, contrary to what people might think?
According to the speaker, what is the result of doing what you love?

options.label: D
options.text: You will become successful, but not necessarily rich

multiple-choice.question: What did the speaker learn from his own experience of leaving a high-paying job to pursue his passion for photography?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: That following his heart was a mistake

options.label: C
options.text: That the money came anyway when he did what he loved

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the key to finding one's passion?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Staying in one job for a long time

options.label: C
options.text: Listening to what others think you should do

options.text: That they all said their life goal was to be famous

options.text: That none of them said their life goal was to get rich

options.label: D

title: One is one...or is it? - Christopher Danielson

multiple-choice.question: What is the main idea behind whole number place value, decimal place value, and fractions?

options.label: B
options.text: To be able to change what we count as "one"

multiple-choice.question: What are the two ways to change units in our whole number system?
What is an example of a composed unit?
What is an example of a partitioned unit?
What is special about units in our whole number system?

options.label: A
options.text: Once we've made a new unit, we can't treat it like the old unit

options.label: B
options.text: Once we've made a new unit, we can only use it once

options.label: C
options.text: Once we've made a new unit, we can treat it just like we did the old unit

options.label: D
options.text: Once we've made a new unit, we have to start over

multiple-choice.question: How many things are you buying when you buy one box of toaster pastries that contains 4 packs of 2 pastries each?
What happens when you partition a partitioned unit?

options.label: A
options.text: You get a new composed unit

options.label: B
options.text: You get a new partitioned unit

options.label: C
options.text: You get a single individual item

multiple-choice.question: Why do we write a one and a zero to represent the number 10?

options.label: C
options.text: Because the one means we have one group and the zero helps us remember that it means one group, not one thing

multiple-choice.question: How many things is 100, depending on the unit?

options.label: D
options.text: It depends on what the unit is

options.label: B

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: It will increase the efficiency of the electricity supply and reduce the cost of electricity for consumers.

multiple-choice.question: What is the purpose of smart metering, and how will it affect the National Grid?

options.label: A
options.text: The purpose of smart metering is to allow consumers to monitor their energy usage, and it will increase the efficiency of the electricity supply.

options.label: B
options.text: The purpose of smart metering is to allow the National Grid to manage the transmission network more efficiently, and it will reduce the strain on the transmission network.

options.label: C
options.text: The purpose of smart metering is to increase the capacity of the electricity supply, and it will decrease the efficiency of the electricity supply.

options.label: D
options.text: The purpose of smart metering is to reduce the cost of electricity for consumers, and it will have no impact on the transmission network.

options.text: A better understanding of the structure of social graphs and their relation to content

multiple-choice.question: What was the speaker's son's reaction when he was shown the clips of his childhood and told that he would be able to show them to his own kids one day?

options.label: A
options.text: He was confused and didn't understand the concept

options.label: C
options.text: He was indifferent and didn't care

options.label: D
options.text: He was upset and didn't want to see the clips

title: The quantified self - Gary Wolf

multiple-choice.question: What does the term "CPU" stand for in computer hardware?
Which of the following programming languages is commonly used for web development?
What is the primary function of a firewall in a computer network?

options.label: B
options.text: To protect against malware and unauthorized access

multiple-choice.question: Which type of database is designed to store and manage large amounts of unstructured data?
What is the term for a type of malware that demands payment in exchange for restoring access to a computer system or data?

What is the primary function of a router in a computer network?

options.label: A
options.text: To connect devices to the internet
